Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: New Crystallization Modifiers for Low Calorie Fats in Food Products
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to facilitate the commercialization of new low calorie fat technology to solve some of the largest obesity and related health issues facing the United States while providing a patentable new additive platform to sell or license to the $600 billion food industry. With high caloric density foods being the primary cause for the obesity epidemic, the facilitation of low calorie fat substitutes will have a powerful impact on the health of a large portion of society, reducing health care costs and providing a positive economic impact. Locally, the development of this technology will result in potential growth of high technology jobs in South Carolina.

The objectives of this Phase I research project are to address the growing obesity epidemic in the US through the development of new molecular architectures for crystallization modifiers a low calorie fat substitutes which have been shown to reduce caloric intake by 90%. Previous attempts to commercialize fat substitute technology, such as Olestra from P&G, have encountered issues with undesirable anal leakage of the fat substitute out of the body which have dramatically reduced their market acceptance. This issue has been addressed by Tetramer, but due to the innovative molecular structures used, a suite of new commercial crystallization modifiers must be developed which can modify the crystallization rates to best match the performance of current natural fat products. Therefore, the key technical objectives are to determine the fundamental mechanism of how Tetramer?s new crystallization modifiers can solve both the nucleation and crystal growth modes governing the crystallization rates during manufacture of food compositions containing low calorie fat replacers. The structure/activity relationships developed will allow a new class of crystallization modifiers to be commercialized which will allow the fat reduction technology to be more rapidly applied to the large markets within the food industry. These new structures could also be applied to non-food applications such as clarifiers for polymer products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data from the USDA show that average daily calorie intake has increased from 2039 in 1970 to 2544 in 2010. Breaking that data down further, the calories from added fats in foods has increased from 337 calories to 550 calories during the same timeframe. For the past 20 years, the development of low calorie fat replacers (LCFR) has been a high priority for the food industry. Unfortunately, products such as Olestra, Salatrim, Benefat and others have suffered from serious commercial shortcomings such as anal leakage, taste, poor mouth feel, and disappointing total calorie reduction. Most common fats have a calorie per gram content of 9 kcal per gram. For this Phase I SBIR Tetramer Technologies has been focused on improving a new low calorie fat replacer technology (LCFR) that has not only a 92% reduction in fat grams (0.7 kcal per gram) but also has been shown to have no anal leakage, excellent taste and mouth feel in confectionary and spreadable commercial applications. This technology has recently obtained full Generally Recognized As Safe (GRAS) approval by the FDA, which is a critical certification for commercialization. In order to maximize calorie reduction it is necessary to incorporate as much LCFR as possible into a particular food formulation/recipe.

Being a new LCFR technology, the currently commercially available food additives used to economically process food products such as confectionaries are not effective. This situation creates a manufacturing process barrier to be solved in order to enable faster commercialization. Solving this barrier to develop a food processing technical “toolbox” in order to incorporate this new LCFR technology into a wide variety of food applications such as confectionary, spreadables, baking, and frying oils has been the main focus of this Phase I SBIR.

Our Phase I/IB progress has been encouraging in that we have identified fundamental relationships between natural fats, such as cocoa butter or vegetable oil, and our new LCFR technology. This basic understanding of how various fats interact with each other and the new LCFR technology will allow Tetramer and it’s food product customers the ability to design and develop compatibilizers that allow for maximum calorie reduction in food products thanks to increased inclusion of LCFRs in food product formulations.

Also during Phase I, we have developed significant interest from a number of food suppliers, one of which provided the maximum funds allowed for our Phase IB, and depending upon the Phase II results, will provide Phase IIB cost sharing. The combination of a very large market driven by the need to reduce obesity creates a powerful commercial value proposition.
